source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: All aloys were taken through a heat treatment at $9 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ , followed by a slow cooling in order to increase the particle size.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: Microprobe analysis of the slowly cooled Zircaloy-2 and Ozhenite-0.5 showed that the intermetallic particles consisted of zirconium, iron, and nickel.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: Also Valoy, slowly cooled from $9 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ , showed selective attack on certain grains, without development of macroscopic nodules, but leading to a rather rough surface.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk4
evidence_span: The analysis of the particles indicated zirconium and chromium only.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Serious nodule formation even on niobium bearing alloys was observed with deliberate fluoride contamination of the autoclave.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Pickled specimens will bring fluorine $( 0 . 3 ~ \mu \mathbf { g } ~ \mathbf { F } / \mathbf { c m } ^ { 2 } )$ into the autoclave.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: The fluorides may be released as hydrofluoric acid by pyrohydrolytic reactions between the oxyfluorides at the surface and the steam, leading to about $1 0 \ \mathsf { p p m } \ \mathsf { F } ^ { - }$ in the steam as the maximum in our case.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: abraded surfaces which were almost fluorine-free obtained more nodules than parallel pickled specimens with fluorine contents in the range of $0 . 5 \mu \mathrm { g } \ \mathrm { F } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: abraded surfaces which were almost fluorine-free obtained more nodules than parallel pickled specimens with fluorine contents in the range of $0 . 5 \mu \mathrm { g } \ \mathrm { F } / \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion was only observed when the hydrogen content was in or near the alpha $+$ delta hydride phase, namely, a region where zirconium hydride can precipitate.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: The hydrogen solubility increases with increasing temperature.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: the lack of nodular corrosion at temperatures higher than about $6 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbb { C }$

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: the alloys having the lowest hydrogen pick-up (niobium bearing alloys and to some degree Valoy), are the most resistant to nodular corrosion in out-of-reactor tests.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: the alloys having the lowest hydrogen pick-up (niobium bearing alloys and to some degree Valoy), are the most resistant to nodular corrosion in out-of-reactor tests.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: the observation that hydrogen addition to the steam stimulates the nodular type of attack

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: prehydriding the material to 300 to $5 0 0 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$ did not significantly affect the initiation of nodular corrosion.

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk5
evidence_span: In hydrogen-bearing steam at $5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ we found that Zircaloy-4 was more susceptible to nodular corrosion than Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk7
evidence_span: The uniform ductility measured as uniform effective strain displays a minimum at the stress ratio 3:2

source_id: STP681-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_4th Volume_006_chunk7
